STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
February 1, 2024
Tracey Ventola
Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee and Hillsdale
425 Ormsby St,
Adrian, MI, 49221-2341
Re: License #: CB460308844
Dear Ms. Ventola:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
1/30/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT

Licensee Group Organization: Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee, &
Hillsdale

homes for license, Place children in foster
home, Evaluate Applicants for adoption

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12306 Application request
(3) An agency shall provide the licensee an application
for renewal of the license and document the action not
less than 60 calendar days before the expiration date of
the license. A renewal application must be provided to a
licensee, regardless of any pending recommendation for
disciplinary action of the license.
One of three foster home files had documentation that an application was not
provided at least 60 days prior to license expiration.
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
(3) An agency shall facilitate in-person contact between
parents and children except where parental rights have
been terminated or when there is a court determination
that visits are detrimental to the child.
One of six foster care files did not have parenting time or attempted parenting time
documented for one month.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
2

Two of three adoption home studies were not completed within 90 days as required.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Two of twenty-three service plans did not have FTMs completed within 30 days
before due date as required.
Repeat violation: 12/6/22 RENEWAL, CAP approved 12/20/22
FOM 801 Medical Passport
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
One of six foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical passports as
required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Treatment Plans must be provided to and reviewed with parents. The case
file must document attempts to do this. Ongoing attempts should be made
and documented to complete these actions and obtain a signature from
the parents on the treatment plan.
• Parenting time must occur as outlined in service plan. There must be
documentation in the case record of each parenting time or
attempted/cancelled parenting time if the parent is not participating.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require or request consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
3

The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. A
CAP, approved 12/20/22, was the result of the 12/6/22 renewal evaluation. In the
2022 review, the agency had five violations regarding borrowed beds, medical
passports, family team meetings, case contacts, and treatment plan signatures.
During the current review, the agency had five violations, one of which was a
repeat regarding family team meetings. The agency reported successful
implementation of the 2022 CAP, which is evident as most of those areas have
improved. A new CAP will be developed to address the current and repeat
violation.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The chief administrator assessment (CAA) was reviewed and discussed. The CAA
reported meeting with staff and discussing the 2022 corrective action plan on a
regular basis, in addition to completing file reviews to monitor improvement and
needs in areas that were previously non-compliant. The CAA reported the team
reviewed the prior CAP and made adjustments as needed, based on their internal
compliance review. The CAA indicated overall improvement in all areas during the
past year. The CAA also noted the agency had some challenges regarding staffing
during the past year. A change in directors at the end of the previous review
period resulted in significant staff turnover. Due to staff shortage, the agency was
unable to accept many cases. In July 2023 the prior director returned to the
agency and has been working diligently to stabilize new staff and increase the
number of cases served by the agency. Hiring new staff continues to be a
challenge due to limited qualified applicants. However, the director is committed to
finding quality staff.
Financial Overview
No financial concerns were noted.
Staff Interviews
Two staff were interviewed on-site. Both staff report they enjoy their job and feel
they have excellent supervisors. Staff report feeling close with coworkers and
receiving support and training as needed. Neither staff had concerns or
suggestions for improvement.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency continues to be located in the same building as the previous review.
The office has secure storage for confidential information. The building has
adequate space for staff and clients.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Analyst identified one safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert: The upstairs bedroom had a lock on the door and several items
were blocking the door. The room was not observed or made accessible to the
analyst. A space heater was located in another bedroom.
4

Resolution: The doorway was cleared. The locked door was one of two doors
into the bedroom. The locked door is not used as it a “dead end hallway”. The
space heater was removed from the other bedroom and training was provided to
the foster parent.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
____________January 31, 2024____________
Heather A Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
February 1, 2024
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
